channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: The best early Prime Day deal gives $10 Amazon credit with a $40 gift card
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Audible, Resident Evil, and PlayStation Plus.

item.title: Reducing poverty can actually lower energy demand, finds research
item.description: Turns out human development is a matter of economic justice and climate justice.

item.title: “Kind of crazy”—how the booming US used car market is driving inflation
item.description: Supply constraints and soaring demand have made vehicle prices a key number for the Fed.

item.title: There’s hope for American movie theaters after all
item.description: COVID-19 crushed movie chains—A Quiet Place Part II’s box office shows a potential way out.

item.title: Early adopters of Chinese vaccines see case surges; China plows ahead anyway
item.description: China is now giving 20 million doses a day despite low efficacy.

item.title: Puppies’ ability to communicate with people is present almost from birth
item.description: We might one day be able to predict which puppies will make the best service dogs.

item.title: Liveblog: All the news from Apple’s WWDC 2021 keynote on 6/7 at 10 am
item.description: Get your updates about iOS, macOS, and more here on June 7 at 10 am Pacific.

item.title: This is not a drill: VMware vuln with 9.8 severity rating is under attack
item.description: Code execution flaw in vCenter is exploited to install web shell on unpatched machines.

item.title: Yes, the military is serious about rocketing supplies around the planet
item.description: “A rocket can get around the world in 90 minutes, and an airplane cannot.”

item.title: “Deleted” Nintendo floppy recovered 26 years later, full of Earthbound secrets
item.description: Oil massages, mantras, zombie kidnappings, and more—with ROM-hacked footage to prove it.

item.title: Researchers perform magic tricks for birds, who are not amused
item.description: Can an animal without hands recognize when humans are using sleight-of-hand tricks?

item.title: Google makes small Android advertising concession in wake of iOS 14.5
item.description: Android ad tracking still isn’t opt-in, though, so not much will change.

item.title: Facebook extends Trump ban, ends exemptions for politicians’ posts [Updated]
item.description: “Newsworthiness allowance” would allow some controversial posts through.

item.title: Ransomware will now get priority treatment at the Justice Department
item.description: Directive comes as ransomware is exposing the fragility of critical supply chains.

item.title: Rocket Report: SpaceX breaks streak of used launches, FAA clears Electron
item.description: “Listen to customers, don’t listen to pundits and market analysts.”

item.title: What to expect from WWDC 2021: iOS 15, M2, and more
item.description: Software is usually the focus, but we’ll probably see a new Mac chip.

item.title: Researchers rewire the genetics of E. coli, make it virus-proof
item.description: A revised genetic code is a pathway for bacteria to do things that seem unnatural.

item.title: Supreme Court reins in definition of crime under controversial hacking law
item.description: Justices reject US gov’s broad interpretation of Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

item.title: Warner Bros. releases trailer for noir-esque sci-fi thriller Reminiscence
item.description: “You’re going on a journey through memory. All you have to do is follow my voice.”

item.title: Samsung will shut down the v1 SmartThings hub this month
item.description: Samsung is killing the OG hub, along with most of the original appeal of SmartThings.

item.title: Sony’s “generations matter” mantra crumbles: Gran Turismo 7 will be cross-gen
item.description: Comes after attempts to differentiate from Xbox’s cross-gen “Smart Delivery” plans.

item.title: The world saw a shark-pocalypse 19 million years ago, and we don’t know why
item.description: Researchers find evidence of a huge shark die-off but aren’t sure what happened.

item.title: Stack Overflow sold to tech investor Prosus for $1.8 billion
item.description: “Don’t expect to see major changes or awkward synergies,” said site co-founder.

item.title: Aviation in 2030: Fuel-guzzling supersonic planes or electric air taxis?
item.description: Both have the potential to alter air travel as we know it.

item.title: Here’s why Toyota converted this Corolla to hydrogen and went racing
item.description: Part engineering exercise, part safety demonstration.

item.title: Virgin Galactic announces another human-tended science flight
item.description: “We’re going to finish our test flight program this year.”

item.title: Attack on meat supplier came from REvil, ransomware’s most cutthroat gang
item.description: Criminals use high-pressure tactics to extort victims.

item.title: This Range Rover Classic restomod runs on Tesla power
item.description: An intriguing and much more unusual alternative to the six-figure supercar.

item.title: No Man’s Sky gets an impressive VR-DLSS performance boost—let’s test it
item.description: Arrives in No Man’s Sky’s demanding VR mode, and we have numbers, image comparisons.

item.title: Physicists unlock multispectral secrets of earliest color photographs
item.description: French physicist Gabriel Lippmann created the first color photographs in 1891.

item.title: Venus is so very nice, NASA is going there twice
item.description: “The Venus community is absolutely elated.”

item.title: Huawei officially replaces Android with HarmonyOS, which is also Android
item.description: Thanks to nearly identical code bases, Huawei can update “Android” to “HarmonyOS.”

item.title: Verizon says forcing people off old plans to get FCC subsidy isn’t “upselling”
item.description: Verizon says it’ll reverse subsidy restriction after “complex” billing-system update.

item.title: SEC struggling to rein in Elon Musk’s tweets, letters reveal
item.description: Regulator concerned that Tesla’s lawyers were not reviewing CEO’s tweets.

item.title: Dunning-Kruger meets fake news
item.description: People who overrate their media savviness share more misleading material.

item.title: Apple’s “homeOS” slip fits with prior rumors about new smart home products
item.description: This is the first we’ve heard of an operating system called homeOS.

item.title: Take $15 off a 12-month PlayStation Plus subscription today
item.description: Dealmaster also has early Prime Day deals, free video games, and Instant Pots.

item.title: One week with Garmin’s newly announced Forerunner 945 LTE and Forerunner 55
item.description: Garmin’s LTE-connected watch is about safety while running. It’s not for talking.

item.title: HBO Max now offers a (partially) ad-supported service tier
item.description: If you’re willing to watch some ads, you can knock $5/mo off your service cost.

item.title: After months of drama, Minecraft speedrunner Dream admits he used mods
item.description: Dream says he “didn’t have any intention of cheating” in controversial speedruns.

item.title: Amazon Prime Day 2021 runs June 21-22, and a few deals are already live
item.description: The two-day sale event is back to its midsummer timeframe, on the heels of an announced MGM acquisition.

item.title: Launcher raises $11 million, ramps up hiring for 2024 flight
item.description: “Compared to our competitors, we are in the kindergarten of fundraising.”

item.title: Review: Nvidia RTX 3080 Ti is a powerhouse—but good luck finding it at $1,199 MSRP
item.description: $1,199 MSRP is arguably worth it—in a universe where MSRP means anything, at least.

item.title: AMD triples Zen 3 CPU cache using 3D stacking technology
item.description: Not a pipe dream—CEO Lisa Su demonstrated a working 3D-stacked 5900X prototype.

item.title: What the physics of skipping stones can tell us about aircraft water landings
item.description: A combination of gyro effect and Magnus effect influences the deflection of trajectory

item.title: Months from the release of Dune 2021, the 1984 version gets a 4K release
item.description: Lynch, who disowned the film, won’t be recording a commentary track.

item.title: Shortages loom as ransomware hamstrings the world’s biggest meat producer
item.description: Add meat to the list of critical supply chains disrupted by the malware scourge.

item.title: Big Tech sues Florida, saying social media law violates First Amendment
item.description: Facebook/Twitter lobby sues over law that protects politicians from “censorship.”

item.title: Xiaomi’s 200 W phone charger goes from 0-100% in 8 minutes
item.description: Charge a phone as quickly as gassing up a car.

item.title: Pirelli puts a wireless sensor in its new tire for the McLaren Artura
item.description: We ask Pirelli to explain its thinking behind the Cyber Tire.

item.title: After 75,000 Echo arbitration demands, Amazon now lets you sue it
item.description: IT-savvy law firms have swamped retailer with arbitration cases.

item.title: ROM site owner made $30,000 a year—now owes Nintendo $2.1M
item.description: The DMCA’s “safe harbor” isn’t so safe when you upload the files.

item.title: Webb telescope launch date slips again
item.description: We “don’t have a lot of reserve” left.

item.title: The US military is starting to get really interested in Starship
item.description: “The Air Force seeks to leverage the current multi-billion dollar commercial investment.”
